instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCORE_SO_CPU: What is PPVCORE_SO_CPU? This is a typo of  When you see PP5V_S0_CPU_IMVP, assume they meant to type .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPUâ€™s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message:
Hi. Dead short on PPBUS and <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMP</SIGNAL>.  No liquid. Both rails beep to ground, OV. <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_CPU</SIGNAL>, 1.8OHMS. CPU does not get warm when power is applied. I have PP3V42 - 3.42V. PPCDCIN - 16.25.
Should I hunt for the short or you think dead CPU already? 

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: Check continuity between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SO_CPU</SIGNAL> coils, if there is continuity then CPU is most likely dead...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: Yeah. Pin 2 of F7041 beeps to L7530.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: There is a fair chance the CPU is toast, if you have time for it you can try to hunt down which mosfet is shorting and replace accordingly, I've had about a 20% success rate on CPU mosfet PPBUS shorts where the CPU was not killed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: Thanks Aprendiz.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: Hey Smiba. Thanks for the advice. Good to know. How would you go about this? 1 volt voltage injection? Or just remove components until short is gone? Thanks man.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: The common fault on this are the CPU mosfets for <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7561</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7551</TRANSISTOR> area. If you inject voltage you will kill the HD4000. Just remove them. this is ivy bridge not haswell so it won't get killed from a bad MOSFET the same way.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: Of course it will beep to CPU Vcore as that is low resistance too. The correct question is: Is resistance from PPBUS to Vcore lower than the short to GND on PPBUS? That would confirm a shorted high side FET on Vcore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message:
Hey Duke. PPBUS is 0.5 Ohms to ground. PPBUS to Vcore is 1.6Ohms. Also, this is with FETs removed. And just noticed some redish probe points under CPU between <CAPACITOR>C1642</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C1723</CAPACITOR>. 
Thanks man. Have a good night.

Thanks Louis, appreciate it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message:
Well that means there is nothing wrong with CPU FETs and you don't need to pull them for that. That is just another risk factor added now.

Inject voltage on PPBUS and see what heats up. Also check GPU Vcore for short to GND and short to PPBUS as a short there is common too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: Hey Duke. Injected up to 2 volts on PPBUS to find <TRANSISTOR>Q8360</TRANSISTOR> is getting hot. Didnt want to do anything else until I posted. Thanks, have a good night.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: Well that sucks cause it is shorted and PPBUS will have gotten to the GPU and VRAM. So expect a dead GPU, 4x dead VRAM, dead <CHIP>U8350</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q8360</TRANSISTOR>/61. Minimum that will need replacing is <CHIP>U8350</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q8360</TRANSISTOR>/61. Pull them all off and measure if there is still a short on L8360.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: Hey Duke, how are ya? I pulled components you advised and I now have .100 in diode mode on L8360. PPBUS in diode .436. Thanks man, have a good day.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: Probably normal as there are a few voltage dividers still present on that line. Put back all known good components.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: OK. So I should assume the CPU mosfets are fine and just put them back on. or get replacements from a donor? Thanks Duke.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: CPU FETs are fine it was just the VRAM supply that fried. Replace everything from the VRAM stuff.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: Replaced all parts. PPBUS is back. CPU VCORE goes from 0.538V down to 0.010V as fan twitches.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: Could be anything. Was this liquid?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: PPDCIN fluctuating 16.78 - 16.3V. Causing PPBUS and S rails to fluctuate as well. PP3V42 is steady. Sometimes green light on charger blinks. 0V on PPBUS with only battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: I would say PPBUS is being pulled down by excessive current. Could be bad soldering on the replaced FETs or any other line pulling this down. Liquid?????

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message:
No, No liquid. PPBUS just shorted to ground again. Found short on <TRANSISTOR>Q7530</TRANSISTOR>. Replaced it and now back to fluctuating DCIN. Im afraid if I keep it plugged in this will just happen again. Should replace all the mosfets to be sure they arent the problem or maybe just <TRANSISTOR>Q7550</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>... since they are tied to <TRANSISTOR>Q7530</TRANSISTOR>?

Update - Replaced Mosfets

CPU VCORE .895
PPDCIN 16.71 (steady)
PP3V42 3.395
Short on PPBUS again. 1.066V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Dead short on PPBUS
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q7530</TRANSISTOR> shorted so now the CPU is already dead. You should never have touched the CPU FETs.....
